<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_commitattr:
```c
static int lfs_commitattr(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }

    uint16_t id = lfs_tag_id(tag);
    if (id == 0x3ff) {
        // special case for root
        id = 0;
        int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &cwd, lfs->root);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_USERATTR + type, id, size), buffer}));
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The code passes the address of the parameter 'path' (&path) to lfs_dir_find. If lfs_dir_find writes through that pointer (e.g. updates *path to advance the path pointer), it modifies the function parameter 'path' itself. MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 forbids modifying a function parameter (the pointer value); therefore this usage violates the rule when the callee changes the pointer value (common when lfs_dir_find updates the path to the next segment).
